parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>The post does not contain a CMF number. While the absence of a CMF number doesn't automatically exclude it from being electoral propaganda, it suggests it might not be directly linked to an officially registered candidate's campaign.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>The post mentions "#DianaMorarudeputat" and "#Cluj".  While it doesn't explicitly name a candidate, the hashtag strongly suggests a reference to a candidate named Diana Moraru running for a position in Cluj.  Further investigation is needed to confirm if such a candidate exists and is participating in the parliamentary elections. If confirmed, this would satisfy Article 36 (7) - a.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>The post is a paid Facebook advertisement, inherently designed to reach a wide audience. The use of hashtags further amplifies its potential reach, indicating an intention to address the public at large. This satisfies Article 36 (7) - c.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>The post's message promotes a vision for Romania and uses hashtags related to parliamentary elections and a specific candidate.  The overall objective appears to be to positively influence public opinion towards the candidate Diana Moraru, thereby influencing the vote. This satisfies Article 36 (7) - c. The hashtags clearly indicate an electoral objective.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>The post does not present itself as journalistic content. It lacks the objectivity and neutrality expected from journalistic reporting. The language used is promotional and aspirational, not analytical or informative.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>The post expresses a vision and aspirations, but it's presented in a manner clearly intended to promote a specific candidate, not to express a personal opinion.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>420253954352755</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The post, while not explicitly mentioning a party, uses hashtags strongly suggesting support for a candidate, Diana Moraru, running for a position in Cluj. The paid nature of the post, its broad reach via Facebook, and the use of hashtags directly related to the parliamentary elections strongly indicate an intention to influence voters.  The content, while not overtly directive, promotes a positive image and vision associated with the candidate.  The absence of a CMF number is a mitigating factor, but not sufficient to negate the overall impression of electoral propaganda.  The fact that the post was published after the official end of the campaign period is a significant factor.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>TRUE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates>
  <candidate><name>Diana Moraru</name><impact>POSITIVE</impact></candidate>
</electoral-propaganda-candidates>
<responsible-party-or-group>FRP TV</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police>
Federatia Romanilor de Pretutindeni, pentru incalcarea articolului 98 t) din LEGEA nr. 208 din 20 iulie 2015, prin publicarea dupa ora 18:00 pe 23.11.2024 a unei reclame pe Facebook (ID postare: 420253954352755), cu cheltuieli intre 300 si 399 RON, care promoveaza candidata Diana Moraru pentru un post in Cluj, folosind hashtag-uri precum #DianaMorarudeputat si #Alegeriparlamentare2024, avand ca efect electoral influentarea votului in favoarea acesteia.  Reclama, desi nu mentioneaza explicit un partid, are un caracter promotional si se adreseaza publicului larg, depasind limitele activitatii jurnalistice, indeplinind astfel conditiile din articolul 36 (7) din LEGE nr. 334 din 17 iulie 2006.  Reclama a atins peste 30.000-35.000 de impresii, conform datelor din Ad Library, si a fost platita de catre Federatia Romanilor de Pretutindeni, cu contactul sedecoro@gmail.com si +40774533702.
</message-for-police>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
